text: (upbeat music)

- I'm Amr Ahmed, and I'm a
cloud application developer
for AWS Professional Services.
I am part of the team that deals

with modernizing and migrating
clients into the cloud.
In our team, we're really focused

on helping all sorts
of public organizations

and governments from their
security defense all the way
to health education and onwards.
The aspect of autonomy with working

with Amazon actually took me
by surprise at the beginning

especially that a lot of
people tend to have this notion

that big corporations
are very bureaucratic
and there's a lot of micromanaging
and it's probably chaotic.
It was quite contrary at Amazon.

You could almost forget
you have a manager.
But being in this role
kind of pushes me to grow personally.
It brings out an entrepreneurial side

in me where I'm thinking
more business problems,
not just a solution or a technology.
At first, when Amazon reached out to me
I was in a bit of a disbelief.
I'm quite young in this field,

and I told myself, Try
it out because why not?

I realized that it's more
than just technical expertise
they're looking for.

They're looking for certain
things in individuals
and they've put it under a set of things
called leadership principles.

My honest advice for
anyone trying to come in

especially the folks
that are very technical,
I would come in with a very open mind.
You're going to learn beyond technical.
You're going to learn to become a leader.
I cannot emphasize this enough.
Leadership principles.
Don't just read them.
Actually, discover yourself through them.
(upbeat music)
